ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to how critically analyze text in creative and unique ways.

In this course, I was able to work on close reading, analysis of text, and texts in conversation. I worked a lot on my writing in this class as well as my ability to look at larger themes within genres. I think this class was a great opportunity to think together as a class about abstract topics and reflect on our own history.

This class helped to expand my knowledge of the African Diaspora as well as engage my close reading skills. We read a wide array of material and each type required me to use a different reading ability.

I am far better at looking at a text and being able to break down said text for deeper meanings based on diction. I am more informed of literature within the African Diaspora and also more versed around the music of African American culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There were only strengths. Rasheed did an amazing job at cultivating an environment where everyone wants to participate and share their ideas, which was great for productive discussions and overall engagement in the class.

I felt that the texts we read were some of the strengths of this course. Rasheed did an excellent job of selecting books, essays, songs, and plays to read as a group which helped the entire class stay engaged. I loved our class discussions and the ways in which discussions continued on after class. I really found a community in this course. 

One weakness of this class was that I wish we had more time for formalized writing workshops. Most of the writing process was done outside of class but it might have been nice to have more time focused on the skill of writing. I feel that I now have a strong foundation in how to engage with academic literature, however, I wish I had more guidance in terms of writing.
This course was my favorite of the year. We read a good amount of books that let us stay engaged without rushing. I cant think of weaknesses to this class.

My strengths came to adding new insight to seminars and bringing nuanced ideas. One weakness is that I need to focus on breaking down texts even further for their deeper meanings and connection to other authors.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would highly recommend this course to another student. Everyone should take a class taught by Rasheed at least once during their time at Yale. I plan to take another class taught by him. Rasheed and his class make everyone excited to learn.

I would. The instructor was excellent, the course topic was unique and specific yet highly applicable to anyone, and the subject matter of the course is one that allows for a close community of students.

Yes! This class was a fantastic building block for my writing at reading at Yale. Rasheed was incredibly supportive of my writing and gave great feedback to my papers. I would heavily recommend this to every student.
Yes I would! The texts and discussions in this class are enriching and pertinent to understanding the diaspora even more.
Yes! The African Literature I read in this class really impacted my life.
